I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support strengthening of the 
Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), with the goal of 
enhancing the effectiveness of ADB safeguard policies and their relevance to the changing needs 
of ADB borrowers and clients.1,2 The TA project will take into consideration the recommendations 
of the Independent Evaluation Department’s (IED’s) corporate evaluation of the effectiveness of 
the  2009  SPS  in  achieving  ADB’s  safeguard  objectives.3 The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  first 
operational priority of Strategy 2030 on addressing remaining poverty and inequality and the sixth 
operational priority on strengthening governance and institutional capacity in relation to upholding 
safeguards.4  
 
2.  The  TA  concept  was  endorsed  during  the  corporate  priority  framework  meeting  in 
November 2019 and is included in the 2020 Management-approved results-based work plan of 
the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Addressing  lessons  from  the  corporate  evaluation  of ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement. ADB is undertaking a review and update of its SPS approved in 2009, following 
completion of the full evaluation of the SPS by IED in 2019.6 The IED 2019 corporate evaluation 
was preceded by an operational review of the SPS in 2014 and 2016.7 IED’s corporate evaluation 
of the SPS provided five main recommendations: (i) the SPS should be modernized based on its 
implementation experience, and on updates of safeguard policies of other multilateral financial 
institutions (MFIs); (ii) a new and pragmatic approach should be adopted for the strengthening 
and use of country safeguard systems; (iii) a new safeguard implementation framework should 
be introduced with strengthened oversight by SDCC and reporting lines; (iv) ADB to prepare more 
detailed policy guidance and operational guidance notes for borrowers and clients; and (v) ADB’s 
staffing requirements to deliver the safeguard implementation framework need to be reassessed, 
and skills strengthened within operational departments and SDCC.  
 
4.  Key issues covered by the IED corporate evaluation include: (i) the need for the SPS to 
better address social issues (e.g., labor and working conditions, community health and safety, 
stakeholder engagement); (ii) the extent to which topics covered by other ADB policies (e.g., 
climate change, human rights, and gender) can be integrated into safeguards; (iii) harmonization 
of  safeguard  policies  and  application  with  other  MFIs;  and  (iv)  addressing  new  financing 
modalities  in  the  emerging  investment  pipeline.  In  addition,  the  evaluation  recommended

2 
improving clarity in delineating the roles and responsibilities of ADB and clients; striking a balance 
between front-loaded procedural requirements and implementation supervision; and aligning 
safeguards to the needs of ADB’s growing private sector operations. The IED evaluation also 
emphasized the need to enhance the oversight structure to achieve more consistent safeguard 
outcomes and maintain quality assurance across ADB’s operations. Keeping in mind operational 
and  regional  differences  between  ADB  departments,  the  new  oversight  model  needs  to 
incorporate provisions for technical backstopping of safeguards staff and measures to avoid or 
manage potential conflicts of interest.  
 
5.  Ensuring relevance of safeguard policies with an evolving country context and ADB 
portfolio. Since the SPS (2009) was approved, ADB has made considerable effort to improve 
the capacity of developing member countries (DMCs) and its clients to manage social and 
environmental risks. At the same time, the country context, development needs, and capacities 
of DMCs and clients have also evolved. From 2010 to 2018, the size of ADB’s portfolio doubled, 
with much of the growth occurring in two areas where client safeguard capacities tend to be weak: 
(i) private sector financing and (ii) support for infrastructure projects in the health and education 
sectors. ADB has also rolled out new lending modalities, such as policy-based loans, results-
based loans, and multitranche financing facilities, that require different approaches to assessing 
and managing safeguard risks. These shifts have led to a more diverse portfolio but have also 
resulted in more complex social and environmental risks. Shorter processing times have created 
additional challenges in relation to safeguards. Furthermore, for the Strategy 2030 implementation 
period (2020–2030), there is a need to consider the suitability of existing safeguard policies for 
fragile and conflict-affected situations and small island developing states.8  
 
6.  Need for harmonization of policies with other multilateral financial institutions. 
Since 2012, several MFIs, including the African Development Bank, the Asian Infrastructure 
Investment Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the  Inter-American 
Development Bank,  the International Finance Corporation, and the World Bank, have developed 
or updated their safeguard frameworks, while others have updates in progress.9 ADB’s bilateral 
partners and cofinancers like Agence Française de Développement, the Department of Foreign 
Affairs and Trade of the Australian Government, and Japan International Cooperation Agency 
have also approved their safeguard policies. The safeguard policies of the different MFIs and 
bilateral  partners,  while  similar  with  respect  to  most  policy  principles,  differ  in  scope  and 
implementation arrangements. In particular, recent updates to MFI safeguard frameworks more 
explicitly consider emerging vulnerabilities such as sexual abuse, exploitation, and harassment. 
They also give more consideration to thematic topics such as climate change mitigation and 
adaption, supply chain risks, and core labor standards and/or labor and working conditions. ADB 
addresses most of these topics holistically through the Operational Plans of Strategy 2030 and/or 
through specific thematic policies; some aspects of these topics are partly covered by the SPS 
(2009). To avoid fragmentation, a careful review of how these topics are incorporated into ADB 
projects and monitoring systems is needed, with key findings from the review feeding into the 
revised safeguard policy. 
 
7.  Ensuring an efficient and inclusive process of updating Safeguard Policy Statement.  
An inclusive, transparent consultative process will be adopted to solicit internal and external

stakeholder feedback and share information throughout the process of revising the SPS. The 
stakeholders to be consulted will include project-affected persons, indigenous peoples, civil 
society organizations (CSOs), government officials, and private sector representatives from both 
DMCs and non-DMCs to ensure that ADB incorporates different perspectives in its review of 
safeguard policies. CSOs representing a broad range of issues and sector interests, and covering 
varied demographic groups, will be consulted. Organizations representing groups that were 
previously underrepresented in consultations, such as the elderly, disabled, sexual and gender 
minorities,  and  youth  will  be  included.  ADB  will  meaningfully  engage  community-based 
organizations from affected communities in the SPS review process. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: implementation of environment and social 
safeguards in ADB projects improved.10 The TA will have the following outcome: governance 
framework in DMCs to uphold environment and social safeguards in ADB projects improved.11, 12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
 
9.  Output 1: Asian Development Banks’s safeguard policies strengthened. The TA will 
support analytical studies to identify strategies for improving elements of the SPS. The studies 
will build on the IED evaluation of the SPS; inputs from ADB staff; consultations with internal and 
external stakeholders, including ADB clients; affected people; CSOs, and MFI partners. The 
studies will draw lessons from MFIs that have recently updated their safeguard policies and will 
build on the outputs of related ADB TA projects.13 Findings from the analytical studies will be used 
to inform deliberations on the merits of feasible options for each element of the revised safeguards 
policy. 
  
10.  Revised safeguard policy architecture. The current SPS policy architecture comprises 
an  overarching  statement  of  ADB’s  commitment  to  ensuring  the  social  and  environmental 
sustainability of its projects and safeguard policy principles; and descriptions of the policy delivery 
process, roles and responsibilities, and requirements for borrowers and/or clients. The TA will 
support a comprehensive study to assess the pros and cons of the two forms of safeguard policy 
architecture:  the  “Asian  model”,  an  integrated  principle-based  policy  (e.g.  ADB,  Asian 
Infrastructure Investment Bank); and the performance-standard model (e.g., European Bank for 
Reconstruction and Development, International Finance Corporation, World Bank). The study will 
review the experiences of MFIs that have recently updated their safeguard frameworks using the 
performance-standard  model.  The  study  recommendations  will  be  used  to  develop  the 
architecture of the revised safeguards policy.   
 
11.  Improving safeguard classification. The TA will support a study that will review how 
other MFIs approach safeguards classification, in comparison to ADB’s practice. ADB undertakes 
project level safeguards categorization separately across environment; involuntary resettlement 
and indigenous peoples followed by separate due diligence requirements for each. Due to this 
fragmented approach the inter relationships between the three safeguards are either not always

11  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

13  ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Safeguards Implementation in ADB Projects. Manila.

adequately captured or may result in duplication of effort in the safeguards assessments. Most 
MFIs recognize the interrelationship between environmental and social risks and have developed 
integrated systems for safeguard categorization. This study will provide recommendations for 
revising ADBs project safeguards categorization system to address all environmental and social 
impacts and risks, and synergies between them. 
 
12.  Background papers on safeguard topics The TA, will review the existing safeguards 
policy provisions for environment, involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples, with an 
emphasis on improved guidance on specialized topics such as: biodiversity; noise and vibration; 
pollution prevention; community health and safety; cultural heritage; voluntary land donation; 
stakeholder engagement and consultation; grievance redress mechanisms; and treatment of 
vulnerable groups. The TA will also study and take a closer look at thematic, cross cutting topics 
and  emerging  issues  which  are  explicitly  covered  by  other MFIs  in  their  recently  updated 
safeguards frameworks. These include: labor and working conditions; primary supply chain risks; 
gender diversity and inclusion; sexual abuse, exploitation, and harassment; climate change; 
issues pertaining to fragile and conflict-affected situations and small island developing states; and 
protection  of  human  rights  defenders.  The  consultants  hired  through  the  TA  will  prepare 
background papers based on the topics studied. The findings will assist ADB in considering the 
extent to which these aspects can be integrated into the revised safeguards policy.   
 
13.  Policy  directions  for  country  safeguards  systems.  The  TA  will  assess  the 
effectiveness of ADB’s past efforts in strengthening and using country safeguards systems (CSS). 
Since 2009, ADB has approved close to $50 million of TA to support DMCs with assessing legal 
and  policy  gaps;  preparing  guidance  on  good  practices; conducting capacity  building;  and 
developing regional learning centers on safeguards. However, it is recognized that the use of 
CSS, which is included in the current SPS as a possible modality, has had limited uptake. 
Regarding the use of CSS, the TA team will recommend more pragmatic approaches for using 
CSS in ADB projects through a range of lending modalities. The results-based lending modality 
could be used as a programmatic tool to incrementally strengthen system capacities across a 
sector. Other possible modalities for CSS integration and strengthening include sector lending 
and multitranche financing facilities, which provide opportunities for longer-term engagement. The 
TA team will also revisit the current approach to equivalence and acceptability assessments, 
considering lessons from other MFIs that have recently updated their safeguard policies. Efforts 
will be coordinated with the Joint Regional Community of Practice on Safeguards.14  
 
14.  Safeguards for new financing instruments and new modalities. Since 2009, new 
lending modalities have emerged that are becoming popular because of their flexibility. These 
include but are not limited to results-based lending, policy-based lending, financial intermediaries, 
general corporate finance, and equity financing. The TA will support an analytical study to 
strengthen and design better-tailored safeguard provisions for a range of financing instruments. 
The experience and approach of other MFIs will again be drawn upon.  
 
15.  Output 2: Safeguard procedures streamlined, and requirements improved. Based on 
the findings, lessons learned, and recommendations from Output 1, policy procedures will be 
updated and streamlined. This will include the preparation of guidance notes for implementing the 
policy provisions for safeguards due diligence. Relevant templates and systems will also be 
 
14 The Joint Regional Community of Practice on Safeguards was established in 2012 by ADB, Department of Foreign 
Affairs and Trade of the Australian Government, Japan International Cooperation Agency and the World Bank.  The 
Community of Practice functions as a coordinating body for the developing Partners’ response to needs of DMCs in 
strengthening CSS, and clearly state the goal of bringing country safeguards to international good practice standards 
as well as ensuring alignment of Partner’s procedures on CSS.

5 
reviewed and revised to reflect the new policy provisions, and to streamline the procedures. 
Furthermore, staff instructions and operations manuals for policy implementation will also be 
prepared using internal resources. Additionally, the safeguards oversight framework will also be 
strengthened.15  
 
16.  Revised safeguard procedures and requirements. The TA will further develop and 
detail the procedural elements needed for the implementation of the revised safeguards policy.  
The TA will review and provide greater clarity for borrowers and clients on their requirements for 
safeguard screening, categorization of safeguards, environmental and social impact assessments, 
stakeholder engagement, and disclosure, as well as additional requirements for different lending 
modalities,  through  revised  operations  manuals,  staff  instructions,  and  technical  guidance 
materials.  Procedural  aspects  of  MFI’s  accountability  and  safeguard  implementation  and 
monitoring of non-sovereign operations, especially financial intermediary, general corporate and 
equity financing will be included. The role of ADB, including SDCC, and operations departments 
in monitoring and supervision safeguards implementation in projects will be clarified.  
 
17.  Revised  safeguard  policy.  Building  on  output  1, feedback from  consultations  with 
stakeholders, and recommendations of the technical working groups (TWGs), a consultation 
paper on the draft revised safeguard policy will be prepared. The draft paper will be made 
available for external consultations and will be further revised based on feedback. The policy 
paper will include but not be limited to coverage of (i) safeguard policy objectives and scope; (ii) 
detailed  safeguards  policy  requirements  for  borrowers  and  clients;  and  (iii)  roles  and 
responsibilities of ADB and its borrowers and clients. The final policy paper will be submitted for 
Board approval. 
 
18.  Enhanced oversight framework for safeguards. The TA will support an analysis to 
provide recommendations on safeguards implementation oversight in ADB. The analysis will 
cover institutional arrangements, staffing, and resources required to implement the revised 
safeguard policies. The analysis will look into (i) how the role of SDCC that can be strengthened 
as the central department for oversight, policy interpretation, problem solving, and capacity 
building; (ii) how the structure and reporting lines in operations departments can be streamlined 
to achieve greater consistency in safeguard outcomes; (iii) the staff complement required to 
deliver the revised safeguard policies; and (iv) further skills enhancement needs for safeguards 
staff. Consultations with and feedback from ADB operations departments will inform the analysis. 
 
19.  Output 3: Stakeholder engagement plan implemented. ADB will prepare a three-phase 
stakeholder engagement plan which will include information sharing and soliciting stakeholder 
feedback and comments throughout the policy revision process. In the first phase, ADB will launch 
the safeguard policy review, share the consultation and communications plan, and lead a first 
round of external consultations to discuss the stakeholder consultation plan. The plan aims to 
understand what stakeholders, including niche stakeholders and women, perceive to be the main 
issues requiring attention during the safeguards policy review. The second phase, during which 
ADB  will  triangulate  the  information  collected  through  studies  it  commissioned  with  other 
stakeholders,  will  focus  on  discussions  around  multiple  proposed  options  for  the  revised 
safeguards policy. The third and final phase will look at outstanding issues and areas where ADB 
needs additional information and will include soliciting comments on the draft revised safeguard 
policy. The TA will support the participation of under-represented stakeholders, independent 
facilitators, communication and meeting costs, and translation of relevant documents into selected 
local languages. Consultation materials, as well as means to submit comments and ADB’s 
 
15 Corporate documents will be prepared using ADB internal administrative budget.

6 
responses, will all be available on the ADB website. In the context of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19)  pandemic,  appropriate  measures  will  be  implemented  to  safely  engage  with 
stakeholders. 
 
20.  Output  4:  Preparatory  measures  for  roll-out  of  the  revised  safeguard  policy 
completed. A capacity building program will be designed to support borrowers and clients in 
implementing ADB’s revised safeguards policy. The plan will include (i) general information and 
awareness raising materials; (ii) training materials and e-learning modules corresponding to the 
policy principles and requirements (incorporating gender diversity and inclusion); (iii) technical 
guidance on specific policy implementation issues and standards; and (iv) long-term capacity 
development plan. This will be prepared to guide roll-out within ADB as well as for borrowers and 
clients. The capacity building program will be implemented under a TA that will be processed after 
the safeguard policy update.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1,000,000 from TASF-6 and $1,000,000 from TASF-other 
sources). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  ADB will administer the TA through SDCC with the support of safeguards staff from the 
operations departments, relevant sector and thematic groups, and non-operations departments. 
The TA will establish a high level interdepartmental steering committee chaired by the director 
general, concurrently chief compliance officer, SDCC and comprising the relevant heads of 
departments to provide overall guidance to the process of updating ADB’s safeguard policies. A 
Lead Coordination Group16 will be established to lead the SPS update process, oversee the 
preparation of the draft and final revised safeguard policy paper. TWGs will be established to 
coordinate and advise the studies on various aspect aspects of the safeguard policy review.17  
The Lead Coordination Group will also provide technical support and advice to the TWGs.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1. ADB’s safeguard policies strengthened

classification; and (iii) background papers in consultation with operations departments. Finalize terms of reference 
and engage consultants (Q4 2020)

departments, OGC, PPFD, SPD, and other relevant departments in ADB (Q4 2020)

1.4 Draft reports and papers from (i), (ii), and (iii) circulated for interdepartmental review (Q1 2021)

1.6 Draft paper of the revised safeguard policy prepared and provided for comments and consultation (Q4 2021)

2. Safeguard procedures streamlined, and requirements improved
